page.title: 04THAMES SAILING BARGES
page.content: Most Thames Sailing Barges are about 85 feet long and 18 feet beam. They have flat bottoms, and leeboards instead of a keel. Most of them were built from wood, but some were steel. Barges are sprit-rigged. They go quite fast because they have big sails. The crew on a barge was small. They were sailed by a man and a boy. Barges were used for transporting hay, straw, coal and gravel, around the East Coast. Now they are mainly used for chartering. Some are still privately owned, and some are owned by companies or their Social Clubs. Barges often visit Pin Mill during the Summer. Each year the Pin Mill Sailing Club organises a Barge Match. The barges provide a splendid sight as they race out to sea and back. After the Match is over many of the barges sail onto the Hard, grounding there as the tide falls.
